annotation.summary: Perception represents a character's awareness and ability to detect hidden details or suspicious elements in their surroundings.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes a passive or general ability.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Perception is a skill used to determine initiative order in encounters and to perform the Seek action. The rulebook provides further details on how to roll a Perception check.
annotation.action_economy: Varies; used for initiative (no action) or as part of the Seek action (typically one action).
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have the Perception skill; no additional prerequisites.

annotation.summary: Describes the three lighting conditions—bright, dim, and darkness—and explains that creatures are assumed to be in bright light unless specified. Light sources specify a radius for bright light and emit dim light to twice that distance.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: Bright light allows creatures and objects to be seen clearly by anyone with normal or better vision.
annotation.prerequisites: presence of bright light (e.g., sunlight)

annotation.summary: Dim light areas cause creatures and objects within them to be concealed unless the observer has darkvision, low-light vision, or another precise non-visual sense.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when an area is in dim light; exceptions for creatures with darkvision, low-light vision, or a precise non-visual sense.

annotation.summary: Darkness conceals creatures and objects from those without darkvision or another precise sense. Creatures without such senses are blinded in darkness but can still see illuminated areas. Sudden exposure to bright light after being in darkness can cause temporary dazzlement at the GM’s discretion.
annotation.prerequisites: Presence of darkness; lack or possession of darkvision or another precise sense determines visibility.

annotation.summary: Describes how a creature's Perception depends on its senses, distinguishing between precise and imprecise senses, and explaining the three detection states: observed, hidden, and undetected. It also notes that vision, hearing, and scent vary in accuracy.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must possess one or more senses to use Perception.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how different species, such as humans, androids, and pahtras, perceive light and darkness differently. It also introduces the concept of special senses that allow creatures to mitigate penalties from conditions like undetected, hidden, or concealed.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must possess a special sense or species-specific vision trait.

annotation.summary: Creatures possessing darkvision or superior darkvision can see clearly in darkness and dim light.
annotation.prerequisites: creature must have darkvision or greater darkvision

annotation.summary: Describes how darkvision functions, noting that it provides only black-and-white sight and that normal darkvision cannot penetrate certain magical darkness, while greater darkvision can.
annotation.prerequisites: creature must possess darkvision or greater darkvision

annotation.summary: Creatures with low-light vision treat dim light as bright light, removing any concealment penalties caused by dim lighting.
annotation.prerequisites: creature must have low-light vision

annotation.summary: Describes how a creature's detectability is categorized into observed, hidden, and undetected, with concealed and invisible conditions providing partial masking and unnoticed indicating total lack of awareness.
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: Conditions such as observed or hidden depend on the perspective of each viewer, meaning a creature might be visible to one observer but hidden from another. These visibility rules also apply to objects, not just creatures.
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: The Stealth skill covers actions like Hide, Avoid Notice, and Sneak to prevent detection by sight or sound. Players can adapt these actions to counter special senses, using the most appropriate Stealth action for the situation.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by action (Hide, Avoid Notice, and Sneak each have their own action costs).
annotation.prerequisites: Trained or untrained use of the Stealth skill, depending on the specific action and game system rules.

annotation.summary: A concealed creature is partially obscured by conditions like mist or dim light. Attacks or effects targeting it require a DC 5 flat check before rolling; failure means the target is unaffected. The condition does not alter detection categories—such a creature can still be observed.
annotation.action_economy: None; applies as a passive condition when targeting a concealed creature.
annotation.prerequisites: Target must be in an environment or situation that obscures sight without being a solid barrier, such as mist or dim light.

annotation.summary: Encounters proceed in rounds where all participants act in order determined by initiative. This structure continues until the encounter ends and can apply to combat or other types of encounters with possible adjustments.
annotation.action_economy: Each round provides a structured sequence of turns for all participants, determined by initiative order.
annotation.prerequisites: An encounter must be initiated and initiative rolled to establish turn order.

annotation.summary: Determines how initiative is rolled in encounters, usually using Perception, but the GM may call for another skill check such as Stealth, Deception, or Diplomacy depending on the situation. Players may still choose to use Perception in most cases.
annotation.action_economy: None (initiative determination occurs before actions are taken)
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters roll initiative using the skill specified by the GM or their Perception by default.

annotation.summary: This paragraph explains what happens when combat ends in the game. Initiative order stops, play becomes more free-form, and the game usually transitions to exploration. The GM may also award experience points or treasure at this time.
annotation.action_economy: No actions; initiative order ends and structured turns cease.
annotation.prerequisites: Combat or encounter must have concluded through defeat, truce, or other ending condition.

annotation.summary: After initiative order is determined, the GM can track turn order using any convenient method, such as a list, cards, or a magnetic combat pad, without needing to remember the original initiative numbers.
annotation.prerequisites: Encounter initiative order must already be established

annotation.summary: At the start of your turn, you regain 3 actions and 1 reaction. Unused reactions from the previous turn are lost. Certain conditions or abilities can modify how many actions or reactions you regain.
annotation.prerequisites: Start of a character's turn in combat.

annotation.summary: At the end of your turn, you first take any persistent damage, then attempt a flat check to end it. Afterward, you make saving throws for ongoing afflictions, and finally, other conditions like frightened adjust as specified.
annotation.action_economy: Occurs automatically at the end of the turn; no actions required.
annotation.prerequisites: You must have persistent damage, ongoing afflictions, or conditions that change at the end of your turn.

annotation.summary: Rules for riding a creature in combat: the mount must be willing and at least one size larger. It acts on the rider's initiative, but the rider must use the Command an Animal action for it to act. Without that command, the mount loses its actions. The Ride feat allows automatic success when commanding your own mount.
annotation.action_economy: Requires use of the Command an Animal action to direct the mount’s actions during combat.
annotation.prerequisites: A willing creature at least one size larger than the rider; Ride feat grants automatic success when commanding the mount.

annotation.summary: Describes how flying works for creatures and PCs, including the need to use the Fly action for aerial movement, possible Acrobatics checks for complex maneuvers, and the use of falling rules if a creature loses flight.
annotation.action_economy: Requires the Fly action to move while airborne.
annotation.prerequisites: Creature must have the ability to fly, either naturally or through spells or items.

annotation.summary: The paragraph introduces rules for handling three-dimensional positioning during aerial or underwater combat and suggests methods for tracking flying creatures' locations.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when combat occurs in environments involving flight or swimming where vertical positioning matters.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains how to record a creature's elevation on a grid and how to establish a reference plane for underwater combat, such as the waterline, sea floor, or another fixed point.
annotation.prerequisites: Use of a battle grid and situations involving elevation or underwater environments.

annotation.summary: Exploration mode is a flexible phase outside of structured combat rounds, where the GM controls the passage of time as players travel, negotiate, or investigate. It emphasizes narrative and discovery rather than immediate danger.
annotation.action_economy: Not governed by rounds or turns; actions occur as determined by the GM.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs outside of encounter mode; requires the GM to define pacing and context.

annotation.summary: Exploration mode focuses on travel and roleplaying rather than tactical combat. Movement is measured over longer distances and time spans, and characters choose exploration activities instead of taking turn-by-turn actions. Daily rest and preparations are also part of this mode.
annotation.action_economy: No turn-based actions; characters perform ongoing exploration activities over extended periods.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies when characters are traveling or engaging in non-combat exploration.

annotation.summary: Players describe their intended actions during exploration in general terms, and the GM determines the appropriate exploration activity and its effects. Detailed descriptions are unnecessary, though some activities may reduce travel speed.
annotation.action_economy: Exploration phase; actions are described narratively rather than using combat rounds.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies whenever characters are exploring outside of structured encounters.

annotation.summary: Introduces the standard activities characters can perform during the exploration phase of play.
annotation.prerequisites: None

annotation.summary: When traveling at half speed, you can make a Stealth check to avoid being noticed. If an encounter begins while you are avoiding notice, you roll Stealth instead of Perception for initiative and to determine if enemies detect you.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be traveling at half speed while attempting to avoid notice

annotation.summary: While traveling cautiously with your shield up, your movement speed is halved, but you automatically gain the defensive benefits of a raised shield if combat starts before your first turn.
annotation.action_economy: None during travel; grants free Raise a Shield effect at combat start
annotation.prerequisites: Must have a shield equipped

annotation.summary: This entry lists the traits associated with an ability or activity, indicating it involves sound, focus, exploration mode use, and sight.
You select a skilled ally who is performing a recurring exploration skill check, such as climbing or avoiding notice, and you follow their lead to perform the same or similar checks.
annotation.prerequisites: An ally who is at least an expert in the relevant skill and willing to assist

annotation.summary: Allows a character to implant or remove an augmentation from a willing creature, with the time required depending on available facilities. Using a medkit takes 1 hour per item level, while a hospital or professional shop can reduce the time significantly. When done during downtime, the activity gains the downtime trait instead of exploration.
annotation.action_economy: 1 hour per item level (medkit), 30 minutes per item level (hospital), or 10 minutes per item level (professional shop)
annotation.prerequisites: Willing creature and access to appropriate medical tools or facilities

annotation.summary: Introduces new exploration activities related to skills in Chapter 4.

The character continuously casts a simple spell, usually a cantrip, while moving at half speed. The spell must take two actions or fewer to cast, and repeatedly casting complex spells may cause fatigue at the GM’s discretion.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast the chosen spell repeatedly while moving

annotation.summary: After an 8-hour rest, a character heals naturally, regaining hit points equal to their Constitution modifier (minimum 1) multiplied by their level, and may recover from or improve certain conditions. Sleeping in armor can affect rest quality.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must take an uninterrupted 8-hour rest

annotation.summary: Describes how characters can be affected by various conditions during adventures, which alter their state or interactions due to spells, items, or other effects.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; conditions are applied as effects rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; any character can be subject to conditions.

annotation.summary: Conditions remain in effect until their duration expires, they are removed, or specific criteria within the condition cause them to end.
annotation.prerequisites: Being affected by a condition

annotation.summary: Conditions with a numerical value indicate their severity, affecting bonuses or penalties by that amount. These values can decrease through various means, and when reduced to zero, the condition ends.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; describes ongoing condition mechanics rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies whenever a condition with a numerical value is present.

annotation.summary: When one condition overrides another, the overridden condition’s effects are suspended until the overriding condition ends, though its duration continues to count down.
annotation.prerequisites: A situation where one condition explicitly states it overrides another.

annotation.summary: The blinded condition prevents the creature from seeing, makes all terrain difficult, causes automatic critical failure on sight-based Perception checks, imposes a –4 penalty if vision is the only precise sense, grants immunity to visual effects, and supersedes the dazzled condition.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when a creature becomes blinded.

annotation.summary: The Broken condition applies to objects whose Hit Points are reduced to their Broken Threshold or lower. Such objects cannot function normally or provide bonuses, except armor, which still grants its item bonus to AC but imposes a status penalty based on armor type.
annotation.prerequisites: Object must have its Hit Points reduced to its Broken Threshold or lower.

annotation.summary: The paragraph explains that certain conditions are related or thematically similar, and examining them together helps clarify their interactions.

Describes how the doomed, dying, unconscious, and wounded conditions relate to approaching death, and clarifies that reaching 0 Hit Points causes a character to fall unconscious with specific effects detailed elsewhere.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be reduced to 0 Hit Points

annotation.summary: The character is deaf, automatically critically failing hearing-based Perception checks, taking a –2 status penalty to Perception checks for initiative and those involving sound, and must succeed at a DC 5 flat check to perform actions with the auditory trait or lose the action.
annotation.action_economy: Requires a DC 5 flat check when performing auditory actions; failure causes the action to be lost.
annotation.prerequisites: None; this describes the effects of being unable to hear.

annotation.summary: The creature becomes fixated on a specific subject, suffering a –2 status penalty to Perception and skill checks, and can only perform concentrate actions related to that subject. The effect ends if the creature or its allies are attacked.
annotation.action_economy: No specific action; ongoing condition effect.
annotation.prerequisites: The creature must be affected by an effect that causes fascination.

annotation.summary: The character is fatigued, suffering a –1 status penalty to AC and saving throws, and is unable to perform exploration activities while traveling.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be in a fatigued or exhausted state.

annotation.summary: A creature that is grabbed becomes off-guard and immobilized. When attempting a manipulate action while grabbed, the creature must roll a DC 5 flat check after spending the action; failure causes the action to be lost.
annotation.action_economy: Manipulate actions require a DC 5 flat check to succeed while grabbed; failure wastes the action.
annotation.prerequisites: The creature must be grabbed by another creature.

annotation.summary: Rules governing how to handle situations when a creature is affected by more than one source or type of persistent damage, clarifying whether the effects stack or if only the highest value applies.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule modifies ongoing damage resolution rather than requiring an action.
annotation.prerequisites: A creature must already be suffering from one or more persistent damage conditions.

annotation.summary: A creature can suffer multiple persistent damage effects at once if they deal different types of damage. When multiple persistent damages of the same type would apply, only the higher damage value takes effect, as determined by the GM if unclear. All persistent damage is applied simultaneously, and any effects triggered by taking damage occur only once per instance of persistent damage application.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be subject to one or more persistent damage effects

annotation.summary: Describes the undetected condition and how creatures can attempt to locate an undetected character using Perception checks against the character’s Stealth DC. Explains transitions between undetected, hidden, and observed states, especially when invisibility is involved.
annotation.action_economy: Seeking is typically a single action; Sneaking to become undetected again usually requires one action.
annotation.prerequisites: The creature must be invisible or otherwise undetected; other creatures must be able to attempt a Seek action using Perception.

annotation.summary: The off-guard condition imposes a –2 circumstance penalty to AC when a creature is distracted or unable to focus on defense. It can apply against specific attackers or situations, or universally if not otherwise specified.
annotation.prerequisites: Triggered by effects or conditions that cause distraction or loss of defensive focus.

annotation.summary: A restrained creature is immobilized and off-guard, unable to perform most actions except attempting to Escape or Force Open its restraints. This condition supersedes being grabbed.
annotation.action_economy: Can only use actions to Escape or Force Open; all other attack or manipulate actions are prohibited.
annotation.prerequisites: You are tied up, pinned, or otherwise physically restrained.

annotation.summary: Explains how the quickened, slowed, and stunned conditions modify the number of actions a character regains at the start of their turn, and clarifies that these changes do not affect actions mid-turn. When multiple conditions conflict, the player chooses which actions to lose, with an example involving haste and slowed.
annotation.action_economy: These conditions adjust the number of actions regained at the start of a turn; quickened adds actions, slowed and stunned remove them. The player decides which specific actions are lost if multiple effects conflict.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be affected by one or more of the quickened, slowed, or stunned conditions.

annotation.summary: Certain conditions restrict specific actions, often reactions, while others completely prevent acting. These conditions don't alter the number of actions regained but stop their use. If such a condition ends during your turn, you can act immediately.
annotation.action_economy: Conditions that prevent acting do not reduce the number of actions regained; they only restrict their use until the condition ends.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies when a creature is affected by a condition that limits or prevents actions.

annotation.summary: A creature that is unconscious cannot act, suffers penalties to defenses and perception, gains the blinded and off-guard conditions, and drops held items while falling prone unless otherwise specified.
annotation.prerequisites: The creature must be asleep or knocked out to gain this condition.

annotation.summary: A character who is unconscious due to dying cannot awaken until they have at least 1 Hit Point. Once healed to 1 HP or more, they lose the dying and unconscious conditions and can act normally on their next turn.
annotation.action_economy: No action required; effect occurs automatically upon restoration to 1 or more Hit Points.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be unconscious due to the dying condition and have 0 Hit Points.

annotation.summary: At the start of your turn, if there is loud noise nearby, you automatically make a Perception check against the noise’s DC to determine if you wake up.
annotation.action_economy: No action (automatic at start of turn)
annotation.prerequisites: You must be asleep or unconscious for the effect to apply

annotation.summary: Describes how a sleeping character may attempt a Perception check to wake up when there is noise nearby, using the Stealth DCs of creatures trying to stay quiet. Some magical or special effects prevent this check entirely.
annotation.action_economy: None (passive or reactionary check while asleep)
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be asleep and exposed to noise or nearby activity

annotation.summary: A creature in zero gravity without propulsion drifts uncontrollably, unable to take normal move actions. It automatically moves 5 feet each turn in its last direction of movement until it gains a way to maneuver. The Push Off action can alter direction and distance. While untethered, the creature is typically clumsy and off-guard.
annotation.action_economy: No standard move actions allowed; may use Push Off action to change movement.
annotation.prerequisites: Being in a zero-gravity or similar environment without a means of movement or support.

annotation.summary: A character cannot have multiple instances of the same condition; if a new effect imposes a condition already present, the condition's duration becomes whichever is longer, and the shorter one ends while any other effects from it may persist.
annotation.prerequisites: none

annotation.summary: When multiple conditions of the same type but with different values affect a creature, only the highest value applies at any given time. Durations are tracked separately, and when the higher-value condition ends, the lower-value one resumes if still active. Any effect that reduces a condition’s value applies to all instances of that condition simultaneously.
annotation.prerequisites: Multiple instances of the same condition with varying values or durations.
